I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen capacity and foster 
multisector  collaboration  in  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs) to promote better integration of water, sanitation, hygiene, and health (WASH+H) to 
prevent, detect, prepare for, and respond to coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and other water- 
and  sanitation-related  public  health  emergencies.  The  TA  will  direct  resources  toward  (i) 
supporting the scaling up and effective integration of COVID-19 infection prevention and control 
(IPC) as well as impact mitigation WASH+H activities into ADB projects in the social sectors (e.g., 
health, education, social protection) and in the water and urban sectors (e.g., water supply, 
sanitation, wastewater, and solid waste management); and (ii) promoting multisector and multi-
stakeholder awareness raising, knowledge and capacity building, policy dialogue, and strategy 
development. 
 
2.  The TA is part of the ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic and is 
included in the 2020 ADB Management-approved results-based work plan of ADB’s Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).1 On a demand-driven basis, the TA will 
help  ADB’s  water,  social,  and  urban  sector  operations  achieve  Strategy  2030,  particularly 
operational priority 1: addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  COVID-19 economic impact. COVID-19 has been costly to Asian economic growth.3 The 
Asian Development Outlook 2020 latest 2020 COVID-19 impact assessment includes gross 
global and regional economic impact estimates.4 Policy responses are thus fundamental in 
assisting Asia and the Pacific to address the economic impacts of COVID-19, and interventions 
that help restructure the economy toward higher productivity growth should be included among 
these responses. Investments in the delivery of water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services 
can  minimize  disruptions  to the  economy;  contribute to  resilient  productivity  enhancement, 
promote inclusive growth, equity, and gender equality; and contribute toward the achievement of 
the Sustainable Development Goals. 
 
4.  COVID-19 infection prevention and control through water, sanitation, and hygiene. 
As highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic, safely managed WASH services, as well as hygiene 
behaviors, are fundamental to protect human health from infectious disease outbreaks.5 Proper 
hand hygiene is one of the most important IPC measures in the context of COVID-19. The 
continuity and sustainability of WASH services and community engagement through (i) enhanced

facilities and products and (ii) the use of multimodal awareness, risk communication, and behavior 
change techniques are critical for improved hand hygiene. About 3 billion people globally and 
nearly three-quarters of people in least-developed countries lack basic home handwashing 
facilities with water and soap. Globally, almost half of all schools lack handwashing facilities that 
include water and soap, affecting 900 million school-age children, and 43% of health care facilities 
lack  hand  hygiene  at  points  of  patient  care.6 Moreover,  studies  consistently  show  (i)  that 
increasing knowledge of handwashing even in settings where access to reliable water supply 
exists is not sufficient to motivate behavior change, and (ii) that multimodal approaches that 
address necessary multiple determinants of behavior change are key for hygiene program 
designers to take into account.7 
 
5.  ADB’s  response  to  COVID-19.  As  of October  2020,  ADB  has  already  provided  a 
comprehensive response package to its DMCs, including projects and technical assistance for 
the health sector. Consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030 (footnote 2), ADB’s post-COVID-19 
support to the region prioritizes the protection of human health via COVID-19 IPC measures such 
as universal access to WASH to combat the spread of infectious disease.8 ADB joined world 
leaders and heads of international organizations in responding to the World Health Organization’s 
14 May 2020 call for action on COVID-19 to make WASH available to everyone, eliminating 
inequalities and leaving no one behind, with a special emphasis on the most vulnerable to COVID-
19, including women and girls.9 The inequitable economic impacts associated with the COVID-19 
pandemic are predicted to disproportionately impact the already poor and vulnerable through 
reduced income, increased risk of all forms of malnutrition, and decreased ability to pay for basic 
services (including WASH) and cover health care costs.10 
 
6.   Need for additional assistance. Additional technical and financial resources are required 
to strengthen (i) WASH components and integration of WASH+H in ADB projects; and (ii) the 
enabling environment, knowledge, and capacity to prevent, detect, prepare for, and respond to 
COVID-19 and other water- and sanitation-related disease outbreaks. The TA for $2 million is 
proposed by the SDCC water and health sector groups to make additional resources available to 
regional departments. The TA aims to promote COVID-19 IPC, resulting in healthier populations 
in Asia and the Pacific through an inclusive, gender-sensitive, effective, and sustainable WASH+H 
program, with a particular focus on the poor, marginalized, and vulnerable who have been most 
affected  by  COVID-19.  The  TA  responds  to  the  demands  of  ADB’s  DMCs  and  regional 
departments, and is being developed with their consultation and that of other SDCC sector and 
thematic groups. The TA will support ADB regional departments in prioritizing and providing 
capacity building and advisory services around evidence-based WASH+H-related awareness, 
risk communication, community engagement and preparedness, and resilience to public health 
shocks (in particular COVID-19) throughout ADB’s DMCs. It will also support multisector and 
multi-stakeholder collaboration, strategy, and policy development.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: human health aspects in TA beneficiary DMCs 
in Asia and the Pacific supported (footnote 2). The TA will have the following outcome: uptake of 
COVID-19 IPC actions in selected DMCs increased.11 This outcome will be achieved through ADB 
and DMCs projects, strategies, and programs. Preliminary countries identified to participate in the 
TA are Bangladesh, Mongolia, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, and Uzbekistan.12 
Confirmation  of  the  TA  beneficiary  DMCs  will  be  carried  out  during  inception,  and  early 
implementation of the TA and other countries may be added.13 A separate, already approved, 
regional TA project is covering Pacific DMCs.14 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Support to projects for COVID-19 infection prevention and control and 
impact mitigation provided. This output will target the scaling up and effective integration of 
COVID-19 IPC and impact mitigation-related WASH+H activities into ADB projects through a 
culturally,  socially,  and  gender-sensitive  and  inclusive  approach.  Based  on  demands  from 
regional departments, TA resources will support project preparation and implementation through 
strengthened WASH+H awareness, evidence-based practices, investments, hygiene behavioral 
change for COVID-19 IPC, and impact mitigation. Eligible activities include (i) WASH+H needs 
assessments (e.g., at the country and project levels), (ii) infection risk communication, (iii) hygiene 
awareness,  (iv)  community  engagement,  and  (v)  behavior  change  campaigns  and  training 
materials development. Assistance from the TA will be in the form of specialists’ inputs and/or 
other advisory and capacity building services, encompassing upstream work (planning phase), 
actual project preparation, and implementation of existing and upcoming projects where required. 
Based on the lessons from the TA implementation, the TA may also support development of a 
guidance note on how best to incorporate WASH+H into future ADB projects, including sample 
terms of reference (TOR) for consultants and sample design and monitoring framework indicators. 
TA outputs can also be used to prepare and implement country-level interventions that can utilize 
and benefit from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction COVID-19 resources. 
 
9.  Output 2: Support for enabling environment, knowledge, and capacity for COVID-
19 preparedness, management, resilience, and sustainable recovery provided. This output 
will  support  multisector  and  multi-stakeholder  awareness  raising,  knowledge  and  capacity 
building, policy dialogue, and strategy development. The TA resources under this output will 
include activities to (i) raise awareness, strengthen capacity, and promote knowledge sharing and 
technological innovation; (ii) identify policy gaps and bottlenecks, and recommend measures to 
address them; (iii) conduct policy dialogue (e.g., water, sanitation and hygiene, health, urban, 
education, gender); and (iv) develop frameworks, guidelines, and strategies to improve COVID-
19 preparedness, management, resilience, and sustainable recovery in DMCs. The output will 
support the development of evidence-based tools, knowledge products, and dissemination plans 
for epidemiological surveillance and utility digitalization, design of innovative pilot projects, peer-

10.  Under both outputs, coordination with partners and technical resources in the region 
working on WASH will be promoted to maximize synergies and avoid duplication.15 To achieve 
this, implementation of the TA will also require a comprehensive inventory of WASH partners 
working in participating DMCs to understand who is doing what and where, and to identify areas 
for convergence and value addition for TA resources.  
 
11.  Communicating key messages to various stakeholders will play an important role in 
undertaking activities under both outputs. Thus, the TA will also explore various communication 
channels and platforms that best suit the activities in each participating DMC. Communication 
channels may include schools, for which collaboration with partners involved in related work will 
be maximized.16 Communication platforms are expected to include various social media platforms, 
noting that they are actively used in many countries. However, some target audiences lack 
internet access, so alternative platforms will have to be developed. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.   The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB.17 The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.   ADB will administer the TA. The Water Sector Group under the Sector Advisory Service 
Cluster in SDCC will carry out the TA administration and supervise implementation in close 
collaboration with the regional departments, including ADB resident missions and other sector 
and thematic groups. SDCC and/or regional departments will select and evaluate consultants, 
procure  goods,  organize  workshops,  and  provide  staff  to  act  as  resource  persons  in  the 
workshops as appropriate.

15.   Consulting  services. ADB  will  engage  consultants  as  individuals  and/or firms  and 
undertake procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and its associated staff instructions. The areas of specialists’ expertise cover the TA scope 
described in paras. 8–11 and will respond to the expected demand from regional departments 
and those that the SDCC will require to support the overall TA implementation across participating 
DMCs. Specialists should include those specializing in COVID-19 IPC and impact mitigation fields 
to deliver TA output activities such as (i) integrated WASH+H project, program, policy, and 
strategy  design  and  development;  (ii)  WASH+H  assessment;  (iii)  WASH  campaigns 
conceptualization and implementation; (iv) evidence-based hand hygiene behavioral change; (v) 
WASH+H advocacy and communications; (vi) WASH-related disease health impact assessment; 
(vii) WASH+H capacity building; and (viii) COVID-19 and pandemic awareness, preparedness, 
and knowledge generation and dissemination.  
 
16.  Project officers in regional departments may request to engage specialists to support each 
project or activity using an application template to be developed for the TA. Once the application 
is approved, the regional departments, in coordination with the SDCC, will be responsible for 
recruiting  specialists,  managing  contracts  and  outputs,  ensuring  timely  disbursement,  and 
providing the SDCC with progress updates. The anticipated scope of work to respond to demands 
from regional departments and to support the SDCC in implementing the TA activities is provided

6 
in the outline TOR.18 To support overall TA implementation, the SDCC will engage at least one 
international specialist. The specialist and/or specialists will help with detailed scoping of output 
requirements to inform the selection of additional specialists for each country and across all 
countries of the TA based on actual demand, including supporting project officers in preparing the 
detailed output TOR. The TA will require 40 person-months of individual international consultants 
and 60 person-months of individual national consultants. Provisions have also been made for 
engagement of a firm and/or firms to support the work on the communication and advocacy 
campaign, and of civil society organizations to support community mobilization and behavior 
change activities. 
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. ADB will procure goods and supplies that may be required for 
awareness raising and behavior campaign materials as described in the procurement plan.19 
Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
its associated staff instructions. To minimize procurement risk, ADB will lead the consultant 
recruitment and oversee the procurement of goods and supplies.

$2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for COVID-
19 Infection Prevention and Control through an Integrated Water, Sanitation, Hygiene, and Health 
Approach, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
